M isery may not be all it’s cracked up to be. Paul Bloom, who is writing a book about suffering, told me, “There's a big movement in psy- chology to say, ‘What doesn't kill you makes you stronger.’ People talk about ‘post-traumatic growth.’ I think a lot of it is bullshit. Look at the data: bad things are bad.” You aren't healthier after you have cancer or fall down a flight of steps. And it’s only in the moy- ies that getting hit by a bolt of light- ning turns you into a superhero; in life, it turns you into a fritter.

The entire time I spent behind the wheel in Scotland | was suftering what psychologists call an aversive experi- ence—that is, I was afraid for my life. The Scots drive on the left side of the road, which is already a challenge, but in the Highlands near Loch Ness there is only one lane. When another car comes barrelling at you, you're sup- posed to pull over on the (nonexistent) shoulder, but this can be hard to re- member when you come around a sharp curve—which happens roughly every two seconds—and find yourself in the glare of rapidly oncoming headlights.
